channel.title: Is compiling always neccecary?
channel.description: Why is it that for many files, like character files, you don't have to compile to see the effect, yet you have to compile to see most of the actual game changes?

item.title: Is compiling always neccecary?
item.dc:creator: @m.dog311 m.dog311
item.description:
@m.dog311 wrote:

The Java Virtual Machine (JVM) loads & interprets the bytecode of the class files at runtime, and translates it into machine code so that it can be executed. The java files are nothing more than a “user friendly” set of files that we can actually work with. The compiler builds the java files into executable class files. The reason you don’t have to compile when you edit things like your player saves, is that your player saves aren’t java. There is code in your server that loads and processes them, and they are loaded as they’re needed (not just at runtime).

Read full topic

item.title: Is compiling always neccecary?
item.dc:creator: @legitz-x legitz-x
item.description:
@legitz-x wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:13, topic:459600”]In short, you need to build (compile) your application in order to execute it.

The compiler transforms the source code into ‘tokens’. In our case, ByteCode is the ‘token’ which is the form of instructions that the JVM will execute.

You as a programmer do not need to understand Java ByteCode at all.

Read more here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_bytecode and here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1419269/what-happens-when-i-compile[/quote]

this is the best comment ever

Read full topic

item.title: Is compiling always neccecary?
item.dc:creator: @Asteria Asteria
item.description:
@Asteria wrote:

Even if you re-compile your code into class files while your emulator (server) is running, you won’t notice any difference as when you initially run your server it loads the dependent classes into the virtual memory.

Read full topic

item.title: Is compiling always neccecary?
item.dc:creator: @ranger_squad ranger squad
item.description:
@ranger_squad wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:16, topic:459600”][quote author=ranger squad link=topic=562518.msg4102284#msg4102284 date=1347640024]
The reason you don’t need to recompile or restart to edit character files is because they’re reloaded when you login
[/quote]

Actually it’s because that the file that is being loaded is read, created, etc. whenever the class is created.

So, say you added a npc-spawn to your configuration file and you have a command to reload all the npcs in the game world, inside that command is: setterForNpcClass(new NpcClassName()) then that will re-initialize the npc-spawn file.

For lack of a terminology what you said is partially correct.[/quote]

Character files are loaded upon login. Therefore, you can change the character file and it will be loaded upon login.

Read full topic

item.title: Is compiling always neccecary?
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

ranger squad:

The reason you don’t need to recompile or restart to edit character files is because they’re reloaded when you login

Actually it’s because that the file that is being loaded is read, created, etc. whenever the class is created.

So, say you added a npc-spawn to your configuration file and you have a command to reload all the npcs in the game world, inside that command is: setterForNpcClass(new NpcClassName()) then that will re-initialize the npc-spawn file.

For lack of a terminology what you said is partially correct.

Read full topic

item.title: Is compiling always neccecary?
item.dc:creator: @JavaTC JavaTC
item.description:
@JavaTC wrote:

Hows this if you can’t understand them:

Player/character files: Just data for the client/server to read to display what’s in your inventory, what models to load for your looks, your bank, etc.

.class: The core game it’self.

That’s the best way I can explain it in simple terms

Read full topic

item.title: Is compiling always neccecary?
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

In short, you need to build (compile) your application in order to execute it.

The compiler transforms the source code into ‘tokens’. In our case, ByteCode is the ‘token’ which is the form of instructions that the JVM will execute.

You as a programmer do not need to understand Java ByteCode at all.

Read more here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_bytecode and here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1419269/what-happens-when-i-compile

Read full topic

item.title: Is compiling always neccecary?
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

[quote=“Fridder, post:8, topic:459600”]I’ll try to make sense of this for you.
Your computer reads the output code (called the bytecode) that is generated from the compiler. The compiler takes the ‘.java’ (class) files and turns them into ‘.class’ files. You can read the ‘.java’ files, but your computer cannot. Your computer can read the ‘.class’ files, but you cannot.

Every time you modify a ‘.java’ file, you need to re-run the compiler, which basically overwrites the old ‘.class’ files with the new ones that were generated from the compiler.[/quote]
This is the best explanation so far.

Read full topic

item.title: Is compiling always neccecary?
item.dc:creator: @Jaxus Jaxus
item.description:
@Jaxus wrote:

The JVM reads bytecode, which is only found in .class files. If it didn’t read bytecode, it would not be platform independent.

Read full topic

item.title: Is compiling always neccecary?
item.dc:creator: @TimeRS3 TimeRS3
item.description:
@TimeRS3 wrote:

Yes you have to compile everytime for java files not for stuff like char files because they are active at all times so the change is instant

Im working on a project rite now where you edit a java file and it will do the exact same as a character file so you see the results rite away making the compiler useless

Read full topic

item.title: Is compiling always neccecary?

Your computer is hungry. .java is raw. .class is cooked. Your compiler is a chef

item.title: Is compiling always neccecary?
item.dc:creator: @Fridder Fridder
item.description:
@Fridder wrote:

I’ll try to make sense of this for you.
Your computer reads the output code (called the bytecode) that is generated from the compiler. The compiler takes the ‘.java’ (class) files and turns them into ‘.class’ files. You can read the ‘.java’ files, but your computer cannot. Your computer can read the ‘.class’ files, but you cannot.

Every time you modify a ‘.java’ file, you need to re-run the compiler, which basically overwrites the old ‘.class’ files with the new ones that were generated from the compiler.

Read full topic

item.title: Is compiling always neccecary?
item.dc:creator: @legitz-x legitz-x
item.description:
@legitz-x wrote:

think of it this way… Acc log in and out makes it like a cfg file, fact that the player can log in and out, if it was a java file it wouldnt work. but making the char log in and out is all created by java… - Player.java+ so u can edit ur acc only if there logged out, and sorted.

Java has to be configed to class files to make the run.cmd connect to class. I guess it has errors if u get cmd to connect to .java. Something like that, not entirely sure. Its what i got told when i was learning java back then.

but i always get told. when ur changing java files always config before making the update.

Anyway goodluck

Read full topic
